issue.title: [loki-stack] loki statefulSet with persistence enabled doesn't start right away due to not recognizing PVC is already bound to it
issue.body:
**Environment**

k8s cluster version: 1.22.6
helm version: 3.8.1
loki-stack chart version: 2.6.1
Cloud provider: Azure

**Description**

When deploying `loki-stack` chart with `loki.persistence.enabled` = `true` and storageClass `kubernetes.io/azure-disk` the following behavior is observed:

1. Seemingly the PVC is created prior to the statefulset
```
  Type    Reason                 Age                From                                                                                               Message
  ----    ------                 ----               ----                                                                                               -------
  Normal  WaitForFirstConsumer   19m                persistentvolume-controller                                                                        waiting for first consumer to be created before binding
  Normal  ExternalProvisioning   19m (x2 over 19m)  persistentvolume-controller                                                                        waiting for a volume to be created, either by external provisioner "disk.csi.azure.com" or manually created by system administrator
  Normal  Provisioning           19m                disk.csi.azure.com_csi-azuredisk-controller-6bcf6bbf9c-lrz89_a2e6446d-133e-44fd-b15d-3f886f2812da  External provisioner is provisioning volume for claim "loki/storage-loki-stack-0"
  Normal  ProvisioningSucceeded  19m                disk.csi.azure.com_csi-azuredisk-controller-6bcf6bbf9c-lrz89_a2e6446d-133e-44fd-b15d-3f886f2812da  Successfully provisioned volume pvc-1a45d6c9-ad33-4eac-b0d0-502a83fc3d4b
```
2. Statefulset starts up
3. Errors prevent statefulset from starting up:
``` 
Type     Reason                  Age                 From                     Message
  ----     ------                  ----                ----                     -------
  Normal   Scheduled               19m                 default-scheduler        Successfully assigned loki/loki-stack-0 to aks-system1-31394726-vmss000001
  Normal   SuccessfulAttachVolume  19m                 attachdetach-controller  AttachVolume.Attach succeeded for volume "pvc-1a45d6c9-ad33-4eac-b0d0-502a83fc3d4b"
  Warning  FailedMount             17m                 kubelet                  MountVolume.MountDevice failed for volume "pvc-1a45d6c9-ad33-4eac-b0d0-502a83fc3d4b" : rpc error: code = Aborted desc = An operation with the given Volume ID /subscriptions/40a4dfee-81c0-4199-8302-3184f180a0b6/resourceGroups/mc_ex-ai-hub-cluster-eastus-dev-cluster-1_cluster-1_eastus/providers/Microsoft.Compute/disks/pvc-1a45d6c9-ad33-4eac-b0d0-502a83fc3d4b already exists
```
4. Statefulset restarts a few time and eventually recognizes the PVC:
```
  Type     Reason                  Age                  From                     Message
  ----     ------                  ----                 ----                     -------
  Normal   Scheduled               23m                  default-scheduler        Successfully assigned loki/loki-stack-0 to aks-system1-31394726-vmss000001
  Normal   SuccessfulAttachVolume  23m                  attachdetach-controller  AttachVolume.Attach succeeded for volume "pvc-1a45d6c9-ad33-4eac-b0d0-502a83fc3d4b"
  Warning  FailedMount             21m                  kubelet                  MountVolume.MountDevice failed for volume "pvc-1a45d6c9-ad33-4eac-b0d0-502a83fc3d4b" : rpc error: code = Aborted desc = An operation with the given Volume ID /subscriptions/40a4dfee-81c0-4199-8302-3184f180a0b6/resourceGroups/mc_ex-ai-hub-cluster-eastus-dev-cluster-1_cluster-1_eastus/providers/Microsoft.Compute/disks/pvc-1a45d6c9-ad33-4eac-b0d0-502a83fc3d4b already exists
  Warning  FailedMount             8m25s                kubelet                  Unable to attach or mount volumes: unmounted volumes=[storage], unattached volumes=[storage kube-api-access-tz8kb config]: timed out waiting for the condition
  Warning  FailedMount             5m42s (x8 over 21m)  kubelet                  MountVolume.MountDevice failed for volume "pvc-1a45d6c9-ad33-4eac-b0d0-502a83fc3d4b" : rpc error: code = DeadlineExceeded desc = context deadline exceeded
  Warning  FailedMount             3m53s (x8 over 21m)  kubelet                  Unable to attach or mount volumes: unmounted volumes=[storage], unattached volumes=[config storage kube-api-access-tz8kb]: timed out waiting for the condition
  Normal   Pulling                 2m32s                kubelet                  Pulling image "grafana/loki:2.4.2"
  Normal   Pulled                  2m30s                kubelet                  Successfully pulled image "grafana/loki:2.4.2" in 1.64499166s
  Normal   Created                 2m30s                kubelet                  Created container loki
  Normal   Started                 2m30s                kubelet                  Started container loki
  Warning  Unhealthy               88s (x2 over 98s)    kubelet                  Liveness probe failed: HTTP probe failed with statuscode: 503
  Warning  Unhealthy               88s (x2 over 98s)    kubelet                  Readiness probe failed: HTTP probe failed with statuscode: 503
```

**Expected behavior**

Stateful set starts up and recognizes the allocated volume claim without having to spend x cycles to resolve correct state

comment.body:
> @vitobotta in my case it would eventually resolves itself, I have simply switched to installing all the charts separately straight from grafana's repo (loki, grafana)

Sometimes I managed to fix by scaling the sts to zero, deleting the volumeattachment if still there, and scaling up again but it doesn't work always.

issue.title: [loki-stack] Loki stores logs on GCS bucket, but doesn't read them from there after restarting the pod
issue.body:
Hi! I have installed the loki-stack helm chart with the values file you can see here https://gist.github.com/vitobotta/c4d6bafdda9d5d755db5e1a9e60b647c

So I have configured it to store the logs to a GCS bucket. Loki stores the data in the bucket as expected (I see a seed file, a 'fake' directory with many files whose names seem like UUIDs, and a directory index/index_loki_(number) with a file inside whose name starts with 'compactor'.

When I query for logs with Grafana all is good, but if I restart Loki / kill the pod, when it's restarted I don't get the old logs with Grafana, as if they were gone. It's as if Loki writes to the bucket, but doesn't read from it. What am I missing? Thanks!

issue.title: schedule_workloads_on_masters
issue.body:
Hi,

i switched the `schedule_workloads_on_masters` setting to `false`, but the ingress loadbalancer still points/checking the master nodes too. Is this the normal working? Is there any way to ignore the master nodes from LB targets?

comment.body: Hi, if the pods linked to the load balancer are still running on masters then it's normal. If you restart the deployment so that all pods are rescheduled on worker nodes only, the load balancer should be updated automatically.

issue.title: Can't run newer versions of docker image
issue.body:
Hi,

when I try 

```shell
docker run --rm -it -v c:\Users\john\k3s:/cluster -v c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh:/tmp/.ssh vitobotta/hetzner-k3s:v0.6.4 create-cluster --config-file /cluster/config.yaml
```

on a windows machine

with the following config.yaml:

```yaml
---
hetzner_token: <secret-token>
cluster_name: cloud1
kubeconfig_path: "/cluster/kubeconfig"
k3s_version: v1.24.4+k3s1
public_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1.pub"
private_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1"
ssh_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
api_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
verify_host_key: false
location: nbg1
schedule_workloads_on_masters: false
masters:
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 1
worker_node_pools:
- name: small
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 4
- name: big
  instance_type: cpx31
  instance_count: 1
```

(I have the public and private keys in folder ```c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh```)

I get 

```shell
Could not find rake-12.3.3 in any of the sources
Run `bundle install` to install missing gems.
```

This also happens for versions before 0.6.4, while some previous versions (such as 0.5.1) do not give this error message.

comment.body:
> @vitobotta Would it maybe make sense to port this to something like Terraform?

Avoiding the verbosity and slowness of Terraform is exactly what drove the creation of this tool. The only problem I am having now is to find the time to complete the rewrite to Crystal which I started and should solve several issues, together with making it easier to distribute standalone binaries that will remove the need to set up a Ruby environment or using Docker. This project is definitely not dead, in case you are wondering. I am hoping to continue working on it next weekend.

issue.title: Not able to browse Documents folder in Mac
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Mac mojave and catalina has new file permission model to improve security (aka TCC). Applications now need to ask for permissions to access Documents/Downloads/Desktop folders.   I installed (and reinstalled multiple times) OWasp Zap in mac catalina 10.15.7. It starts up fine, however when trying to open a previously stored session (from another laptop) in my documents folder, I am not able to see any files/folder inside Documents folder. This is same for Desktop and downloads folder. (Presumably because of Mac's TCC permissions.). I tried resetting TCC for org.zaproxy.zap.ZAP and gave 'full disk' permissions to Zap. However even after that Zap is not able to see any files/folders in above folders.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open Zap
2. Click 'File' menu
3. Click 'Open Session'
4. Set file selector to 'All files.
5. Browse to Documents folder
6. Observe that no files/folders are visible.
7. If browseing to any other folder other than Documents/Downloads/Desktop folders, all files and folders are visible normally.

**Expected behavior**
Files/folder should be visible.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3331518/107417382-6081f600-6aca-11eb-80f1-f3eb444ffe6f.png)

**Software versions**
 - ZAP: 2.10.0
 - Add-on: None
 - OS: MacOs Catalina 10.15.7 (19H2)
 - Java: Zap inbuilt jdk
 - Browser: Not applicable

**Errors from the zap.log file**
No errors in log file related to file dialog.

**Additional context**
Tried following things and none of them worked.
1) Tried reinstalling Zap multiple times. Zap never asked me for tcc permissions
2) Gave full disk permissions to Zap in Mac Privacy settings.
2) Reset tcc permissions using 'sudo tccutil reset All org.zaproxy.zap.ZAP'
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3331518/107417736-be164280-6aca-11eb-92d5-d465f40209a6.png)


**Would you like to help fix this issue?**
Can provide any logs or debugging steps to reproduce the issue

Ideally, Zap could be made more compliant with Mac Tcc so it prompts for Tcc permission and shows up as available application to configure in Privacy settings for better management of TCC permissions.

comment.body:
> Same issues. "Full Access" didn't help.
> 
> Because I've given `Terminal.app` access, I'm able to access `~/Downloads` when I start it from the CLI as so:
> 
> ```
> $ /Applications/OWASP\ ZAP.app/Contents/Java/zap.sh
> ```

This is pretty annoying but at least it works, thanks.  I added an alias to my .zshrc

```bash
alias zap="/Applications/OWASP\ ZAP.app/Contents/Java/zap.sh 2>&1 > /dev/null  &"
```

So I just type `zap` in the terminal and am not bothered with the ouput.

issue.title: RPC memory usage - pods OOMkilled with 4GB allocated per pod
issue.body:
<!--
  First of all, thanks for your report/suggestion/whatever!

  This template is for bug reports. If you are reporting a bug, please continue on.
  If you are here for another reason, please, go to discussions: https://github.com/anycable/anycable/discussions

  Please, check the documentation website (https://docs.anycable.io/),
  especially, the "Troubleshooting" section (https://docs.anycable.io/troubleshooting)
  before submiting the issue.
-->

### Tell us about your environment

**Ruby version:**
3.1.2

**Rails version:**
7.0.4

**`anycable` gem version:**
1.2.3

**`anycable-rails` gem version:**
1.3.3

**`grpc` gem version:**
1.45.0

### What did you do?

I have been using AnyCable for a while already, but at the moment I am doing general load tests for our app with Locust.

### What did you expect to happen?

RPC process to function correctly with 4GB of RAM allocated per process/pod (Kubernetes).

### What actually happened?

The RPC processes get OOMKilled by Kubernetes very quickly and keep restarting, despite there isn't much activity really. 

Can you advise on how much memory each RPC process is supposed to use? I think that 4GB of RAM are already a lot considering that it's a single Rails process, and I have tried lowering the threads from 40 to 20, with no success. The RPC processes get OOMKilled in a very short time from restarting, so it doesn't happen after a while. Seems like a memory leak or something like that.

Thanks in advance for your help!

comment.body: Thanks @palkan , if it happens again I will try a different version of that gem.

pull_request.title: Increase subnet mask to 24
pull_request.body:
Increase of subnet mask to 24 would gives the possibility to add vSwitch to the network. Currently the network and only existing subnet have the same subnet mask and therefor any other subnet has an overlap and is denied.
With a vSwitch I could probably connect a dedicated server to the cloud.

issue.title: RPC memory usage - pods OOMkilled with 4GB allocated per pod
issue.body:
<!--
  First of all, thanks for your report/suggestion/whatever!

  This template is for bug reports. If you are reporting a bug, please continue on.
  If you are here for another reason, please, go to discussions: https://github.com/anycable/anycable/discussions

  Please, check the documentation website (https://docs.anycable.io/),
  especially, the "Troubleshooting" section (https://docs.anycable.io/troubleshooting)
  before submiting the issue.
-->

### Tell us about your environment

**Ruby version:**
3.1.2

**Rails version:**
7.0.4

**`anycable` gem version:**
1.2.3

**`anycable-rails` gem version:**
1.3.3

**`grpc` gem version:**
1.45.0

### What did you do?

I have been using AnyCable for a while already, but at the moment I am doing general load tests for our app with Locust.

### What did you expect to happen?

RPC process to function correctly with 4GB of RAM allocated per process/pod (Kubernetes).

### What actually happened?

The RPC processes get OOMKilled by Kubernetes very quickly and keep restarting, despite there isn't much activity really. 

Can you advise on how much memory each RPC process is supposed to use? I think that 4GB of RAM are already a lot considering that it's a single Rails process, and I have tried lowering the threads from 40 to 20, with no success. The RPC processes get OOMKilled in a very short time from restarting, so it doesn't happen after a while. Seems like a memory leak or something like that.

Thanks in advance for your help!

issue.title: locust k8s operator
issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Need for flexible, secure and easy to use distributed performance testing solution while enabling keeping in mind points like; cloud governance, k8s resource management, CI compatibility. 


### Describe the solution you'd like
A k8s operator

### Describe alternatives you've considered
HELM. However, this is not optimal as it requires a lot of manipulation and dealing with a lot of different k8s resource types not to mention lack of governance when deployed in an organisation. 

 
### Additional context
In my company, we were interested in cloud based distributed performance testing. We ended up choosing “locust” as a tool and I wrote a kubernetes operator for it. As far as I know and searched, this simply doesn’t exist for locust today.The operator have been running on AWS EKS for months now and it is very stable and performant.

The project was created to provide:
- A friendly user interface "A simple k8s custom resource based on a CRD"
- Ability to run a distributed performance testing
- Only ask for needed cluster permissions (security) 
- Exposing a Prometheus endpoint for test metrics
- Maintain cloud infrastructure governance i.e. when used in an organisation,  it is possible to maintain the governance over the allocated / created resources. 
- Cloud native by design 
- Enablement of performance testing in CI / CD pipelines

The project was inspired after doing an industry study / survey. 
The project was influenced in functionality by the k6 k8s operator.

As the code really doesn't include anything exclusive to the company, Open sourcing it is not a problem and it is something that I would happily do. 

What is the "catch"? 
The only "catch" is that the project is written in Java. That being said, from a user perspective, the interface purely through k8s and users are not exposed to any java code.  This is similar to how k8s and most operators are written in Go but non of k8s users need to know anything about Go. 

Looking forward to your feedback.

comment.body: Hi @AbdelrhmanHamouda ! This looks amazing! I checked the docs and would like to give it a try. How do I open the UI when a test is running?

issue.title: Document labels used by Okteto pods
Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
issue.body:
Hi,

I appreciate your work a lot, I got me going with k3s and I using it constantly for learning purposes. I'm using your project for about a year now and it worked great until I upgraded my hetzner-k3s binary (running on Linux). No matter what I do, I get the error:  Invalid Hetzner Cloud token.

I ran: 
- `hetzner-k3s create-cluster --config-file=config.yaml`
- `hetzner-k3s upgrade-cluster --config-file=config.yaml --new-k3s-version v1.24.4+k3s1`
- I created the config file from scratch by using the example from the instructions
- Created a few new Hetzner Projects and API Tokens at them with read and write permissions
- I checked my env vars (HCLOUD_TOKEN is not set)
- Tried with and without qoutes around the token in the config file
- I tested the Hetzner API by running `curl  -H "Authorization: Bearer $API_TOKEN"   'https://api.hetzner.cloud/v1/server_types'` with the API Token and that works fine. 
- I tried versions 0.6.0 until 0.6.5.pre1
- I even tried the docker version

In al cases I get the error: 
```
Some information in the configuration file requires your attention:
 - Invalid Hetzner Cloud token
```

I hope I didn't make a simple mistake. Do you have any idea what the problem can be?

Thanks in advance

issue.title: Document labels used by Okteto pods
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Documentation request

**Describe the solution you'd like**
In my case, I use a wrapper around some K8s tools including Okteto to abstract some complexity, and am also using KEDA autoscaling to scale my app. When I start Okteto, the autoscaler interferes because it automatically starts its own non-Okteto pods, so traffic is then split between Okteto pods and the autoscaler pods, causing problems and confusion. For this reason, I changed my CLI so that before starting Okteto it patches the services so that they send traffic only to the Okteto pods, ignoring the autoscaled pods. So I can work with Okteto just fine. 

This wasn't documented, so I had to figure out that Okteto labels the pod for the main service with the label "interactive.dev.okteto.com" and the additional services (as specified in the manifest) with "detached.dev.okteto.com".

By patching my services to use these labels during an Okteto session, I no longer have problems due to the autoscaling.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I couldn't think of an alternative

issue.body:
So, I have added to my config file code bellow. But I see also ability add some packages with `additional_packages`. How that works in different OS? and what about lifecycle? As I understand post_create_commands will be last one for running? If I want to update or add extra nodes will be additional_packages and post_create_commands run for active nodes? 

and how I can labeled nodes in setup way? Does it works https://github.com/vitobotta/hetzner-k3s/issues/98 ?

```
post_create_commands:
- apt update && apt upgrade -y
# Fix for K3s on Debian (Pods can't be scheduled)
- apt -y install apparmor apparmor-utils
#
- apt -y install mc htop vim wget git zsh podman iftop atop lsof fail2ban jq make
#
- apt -y install tmux tmuxinator
- git clone https://github.com/gpakosz/.tmux.git /root/.tmux ; ln -s -f /root/.tmux/.tmux.conf /root/ ; cp /root/.tmux/.tmux.conf.local /root/

- shutdown -r now
```

comment.body:
Hi, 

- installing packages you specify happens only once the nodes are first created. If you want to upgrade them or install something else after the fact, you need to SSH into the nodes and do it manually.
- The machines are provided by default with Ubuntu unless you specify another image, so the packages and the commands you specify should match that
- If you add new nodes to an existing cluster, it will run the post commands and install the additional packages on them as expected
- the node labelling was introduced in v0.6.2 IIRC but I recommend you use the gem because there are some issues with the binaries. I am currently rewriting the tool in Crystal to be able to offer proper binaries and solve some other issues I have with the Ruby version. If you have problems with 0.6.2 I recommend you stick to a release from before I introduced this changes, 0.5.9 and label the nodes manually for now.

issue.title: Use of cache doesn't seem to speed up much
issue.body:
## Expected Behavior

Using cache should improve performance significantly.

## Actual Behavior

For example I have an endpoint that serializes 7700 records that also include associations. The queries are fast, but generating the serialized response takes 5 seconds at least (I'm already using the oj gem).

I have enabled caching and I can see it creates one individual Redis key for each record and for its associated records too.
But the serialization takes more or less the same time basically.

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Add caching configuration to the relevant models (main model as well as the associated models)
  2. Run the serializer the first time, it creates the keys in Redis
  3. Run the serializer the second time with the same data, this is not faster than without caching

## Specifications

  - Version: 2.2.0
  - Ruby version: 3.1.2


Thanks in advance.

- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Container-Optimized OS from Google 
- Kernel version: 5.4.144+

How was the ingress-nginx-controller installed:
Using helm template , using the command: 

`helm install ingress-nginx ingress-nginx/ingress-nginx --set controller.extraArgs.size-buckets="{0.05,0.1,0.3,0.5,1.0,5,10}"`

Output of 'helm ls -A | grep -i ingress'

**What happened**:

ps. This is in my puma.rb

```ruby
on_worker_boot do

    require 'prometheus_exporter/instrumentation'

    PrometheusExporter::Instrumentation::Puma.start
  end
end
```

issue.title: [loki-stack] Loki stores logs on GCS bucket, but doesn't read them from there after restarting the pod
issue.body:
Hi! I have installed the loki-stack helm chart with the values file you can see here https://gist.github.com/vitobotta/c4d6bafdda9d5d755db5e1a9e60b647c

So I have configured it to store the logs to a GCS bucket. Loki stores the data in the bucket as expected (I see a seed file, a 'fake' directory with many files whose names seem like UUIDs, and a directory index/index_loki_(number) with a file inside whose name starts with 'compactor'.

When I query for logs with Grafana all is good, but if I restart Loki / kill the pod, when it's restarted I don't get the old logs with Grafana, as if they were gone. It's as if Loki writes to the bucket, but doesn't read from it. What am I missing? Thanks!

issue.title: Can't run newer versions of docker image
issue.body:
Hi,

when I try 

```shell
docker run --rm -it -v c:\Users\john\k3s:/cluster -v c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh:/tmp/.ssh vitobotta/hetzner-k3s:v0.6.4 create-cluster --config-file /cluster/config.yaml
```

on a windows machine

with the following config.yaml:

```yaml
---
hetzner_token: <secret-token>
cluster_name: cloud1
kubeconfig_path: "/cluster/kubeconfig"
k3s_version: v1.24.4+k3s1
public_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1.pub"
private_ssh_key_path: "/tmp/.ssh/id_rsa_hetz1"
ssh_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
api_allowed_networks:
  - 0.0.0.0/0
verify_host_key: false
location: nbg1
schedule_workloads_on_masters: false
masters:
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 1
worker_node_pools:
- name: small
  instance_type: cpx21
  instance_count: 4
- name: big
  instance_type: cpx31
  instance_count: 1
```

(I have the public and private keys in folder ```c:\Users\john\k3s\ssh```)

I get 

```shell
Could not find rake-12.3.3 in any of the sources
Run `bundle install` to install missing gems.
```

This also happens for versions before 0.6.4, while some previous versions (such as 0.5.1) do not give this error message.

comment.body:
> @vitobotta Would it maybe make sense to port this to something like Terraform?

Avoiding the verbosity and slowness of Terraform is exactly what drove the creation of this tool. The only problem I am having now is to find the time to complete the rewrite to Crystal which I started and should solve several issues, together with making it easier to distribute standalone binaries that will remove the need to set up a Ruby environment or using Docker. This project is definitely not dead, in case you are wondering. I am hoping to continue working on it next weekend.

issue.title: Not able to browse Documents folder in Mac
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Mac mojave and catalina has new file permission model to improve security (aka TCC). Applications now need to ask for permissions to access Documents/Downloads/Desktop folders.   I installed (and reinstalled multiple times) OWasp Zap in mac catalina 10.15.7. It starts up fine, however when trying to open a previously stored session (from another laptop) in my documents folder, I am not able to see any files/folder inside Documents folder. This is same for Desktop and downloads folder. (Presumably because of Mac's TCC permissions.). I tried resetting TCC for org.zaproxy.zap.ZAP and gave 'full disk' permissions to Zap. However even after that Zap is not able to see any files/folders in above folders.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open Zap
2. Click 'File' menu
3. Click 'Open Session'
4. Set file selector to 'All files.
5. Browse to Documents folder
6. Observe that no files/folders are visible.
7. If browseing to any other folder other than Documents/Downloads/Desktop folders, all files and folders are visible normally.

**Expected behavior**
Files/folder should be visible.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3331518/107417382-6081f600-6aca-11eb-80f1-f3eb444ffe6f.png)

**Software versions**
 - ZAP: 2.10.0
 - Add-on: None
 - OS: MacOs Catalina 10.15.7 (19H2)
 - Java: Zap inbuilt jdk
 - Browser: Not applicable

**Errors from the zap.log file**
No errors in log file related to file dialog.

**Additional context**
Tried following things and none of them worked.
1) Tried reinstalling Zap multiple times. Zap never asked me for tcc permissions
2) Gave full disk permissions to Zap in Mac Privacy settings.
2) Reset tcc permissions using 'sudo tccutil reset All org.zaproxy.zap.ZAP'
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3331518/107417736-be164280-6aca-11eb-92d5-d465f40209a6.png)


**Would you like to help fix this issue?**
Can provide any logs or debugging steps to reproduce the issue

Ideally, Zap could be made more compliant with Mac Tcc so it prompts for Tcc permission and shows up as available application to configure in Privacy settings for better management of TCC permissions.

comment.body:
> Same issues. "Full Access" didn't help.
> 
> Because I've given `Terminal.app` access, I'm able to access `~/Downloads` when I start it from the CLI as so:
> 
> ```
> $ /Applications/OWASP\ ZAP.app/Contents/Java/zap.sh
> ```

This is pretty annoying but at least it works, thanks.  I added an alias to my .zshrc

```bash
alias zap="/Applications/OWASP\ ZAP.app/Contents/Java/zap.sh 2>&1 > /dev/null  &"
```

So I just type `zap` in the terminal and am not bothered with the ouput.

issue.title: RPC memory usage - pods OOMkilled with 4GB allocated per pod
issue.body:
<!--
  First of all, thanks for your report/suggestion/whatever!

  This template is for bug reports. If you are reporting a bug, please continue on.
  If you are here for another reason, please, go to discussions: https://github.com/anycable/anycable/discussions

  Please, check the documentation website (https://docs.anycable.io/),
  especially, the "Troubleshooting" section (https://docs.anycable.io/troubleshooting)
  before submiting the issue.
-->

### Tell us about your environment

**Ruby version:**
3.1.2

**Rails version:**
7.0.4

**`anycable` gem version:**
1.2.3

**`anycable-rails` gem version:**
1.3.3

**`grpc` gem version:**
1.45.0

### What did you do?

I have been using AnyCable for a while already, but at the moment I am doing general load tests for our app with Locust.

### What did you expect to happen?

RPC process to function correctly with 4GB of RAM allocated per process/pod (Kubernetes).

### What actually happened?

The RPC processes get OOMKilled by Kubernetes very quickly and keep restarting, despite there isn't much activity really. 

Can you advise on how much memory each RPC process is supposed to use? I think that 4GB of RAM are already a lot considering that it's a single Rails process, and I have tried lowering the threads from 40 to 20, with no success. The RPC processes get OOMKilled in a very short time from restarting, so it doesn't happen after a while. Seems like a memory leak or something like that.

Thanks in advance for your help!

issue.title: locust k8s operator
issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Need for flexible, secure and easy to use distributed performance testing solution while enabling keeping in mind points like; cloud governance, k8s resource management, CI compatibility. 


### Describe the solution you'd like
A k8s operator

### Describe alternatives you've considered
HELM. However, this is not optimal as it requires a lot of manipulation and dealing with a lot of different k8s resource types not to mention lack of governance when deployed in an organisation. 

 
### Additional context
In my company, we were interested in cloud based distributed performance testing. We ended up choosing “locust” as a tool and I wrote a kubernetes operator for it. As far as I know and searched, this simply doesn’t exist for locust today.The operator have been running on AWS EKS for months now and it is very stable and performant.

The project was created to provide:
- A friendly user interface "A simple k8s custom resource based on a CRD"
- Ability to run a distributed performance testing
- Only ask for needed cluster permissions (security) 
- Exposing a Prometheus endpoint for test metrics
- Maintain cloud infrastructure governance i.e. when used in an organisation,  it is possible to maintain the governance over the allocated / created resources. 
- Cloud native by design 
- Enablement of performance testing in CI / CD pipelines

The project was inspired after doing an industry study / survey. 
The project was influenced in functionality by the k6 k8s operator.

As the code really doesn't include anything exclusive to the company, Open sourcing it is not a problem and it is something that I would happily do. 

What is the "catch"? 
The only "catch" is that the project is written in Java. That being said, from a user perspective, the interface purely through k8s and users are not exposed to any java code.  This is similar to how k8s and most operators are written in Go but non of k8s users need to know anything about Go. 

Looking forward to your feedback.

issue.title: Document labels used by Okteto pods
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Documentation request

**Describe the solution you'd like**
In my case, I use a wrapper around some K8s tools including Okteto to abstract some complexity, and am also using KEDA autoscaling to scale my app. When I start Okteto, the autoscaler interferes because it automatically starts its own non-Okteto pods, so traffic is then split between Okteto pods and the autoscaler pods, causing problems and confusion. For this reason, I changed my CLI so that before starting Okteto it patches the services so that they send traffic only to the Okteto pods, ignoring the autoscaled pods. So I can work with Okteto just fine. 

This wasn't documented, so I had to figure out that Okteto labels the pod for the main service with the label "interactive.dev.okteto.com" and the additional services (as specified in the manifest) with "detached.dev.okteto.com".

By patching my services to use these labels during an Okteto session, I no longer have problems due to the autoscaling.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I couldn't think of an alternative

comment.body:
Hi, 

- installing packages you specify happens only once the nodes are first created. If you want to upgrade them or install something else after the fact, you need to SSH into the nodes and do it manually.
- The machines are provided by default with Ubuntu unless you specify another image, so the packages and the commands you specify should match that
- If you add new nodes to an existing cluster, it will run the post commands and install the additional packages on them as expected
- the node labelling was introduced in v0.6.2 IIRC but I recommend you use the gem because there are some issues with the binaries. I am currently rewriting the tool in Crystal to be able to offer proper binaries and solve some other issues I have with the Ruby version. If you have problems with 0.6.2 I recommend you stick to a release from before I introduced this changes, 0.5.9 and label the nodes manually for now.

issue.title: Use of cache doesn't seem to speed up much
issue.body:
## Expected Behavior

Using cache should improve performance significantly.

## Actual Behavior

For example I have an endpoint that serializes 7700 records that also include associations. The queries are fast, but generating the serialized response takes 5 seconds at least (I'm already using the oj gem).

I have enabled caching and I can see it creates one individual Redis key for each record and for its associated records too.
But the serialization takes more or less the same time basically.

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Add caching configuration to the relevant models (main model as well as the associated models)
  2. Run the serializer the first time, it creates the keys in Redis
  3. Run the serializer the second time with the same data, this is not faster than without caching

## Specifications

  - Version: 2.2.0
  - Ruby version: 3.1.2


Thanks in advance.

issue.body:
NGINX Ingress controller
Release: v1.1.1
nginx version: nginx/1.19.9

**Kubernetes version (use kubectl version):**
Client Version: version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"23", GitVersion:"v1.23.3", GitCommit:"816c97ab8cff8a1c72eccca1026f7820e93e0d25", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2022-01-25T21:25:17Z", GoVersion:"go1.17.6", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"linux/amd64"}
Server Version: version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"20+", GitVersion:"v1.20.12-gke.1500", GitCommit:"d32c0db9a3ccd0ac73b0b3abd0532505217b376e", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2021-11-17T09:30:02Z", GoVersion:"go1.15.15b5", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"linux/amd64"}

**Helm version:**
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.7.0", GitCommit:"eeac83883cb4014fe60267ec6373570374ce770b", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.16.8"}

**Environment:**
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: GCP GKE
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Container-Optimized OS from Google 
- Kernel version: 5.4.144+

How was the ingress-nginx-controller installed:
Using helm template , using the command: 

`helm install ingress-nginx ingress-nginx/ingress-nginx --set controller.extraArgs.size-buckets="{0.05,0.1,0.3,0.5,1.0,5,10}"`

Output of 'helm ls -A | grep -i ingress'
ingress-nginx	default  	1       	2022-02-10 12:35:46.167462946 +0200 EET	deployed	ingress-nginx-4.0.17	1.1.1 

**Current State of the controller**:
```
➜  kubectl get pod
NAME                                        READY   STATUS             RESTARTS   AGE
ingress-nginx-controller-7bdc9d4dc8-dtkc2   0/1     CrashLoopBackOff   10         27m
```

```
➜  kubectl describe ingressclasses
Name:         nginx
Labels:       app.kubernetes.io/component=controller
              app.kubernetes.io/instance=ingress-nginx
              app.kubernetes.io/managed-by=Helm
              app.kubernetes.io/name=ingress-nginx
              app.kubernetes.io/part-of=ingress-nginx
              app.kubernetes.io/version=1.1.1
              helm.sh/chart=ingress-nginx-4.0.17
Annotations:  meta.helm.sh/release-name: ingress-nginx
              meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: default
Controller:   k8s.io/ingress-nginx
Events:       <none>
```


```
➜  ~ kubectl logs -f ingress-nginx-controller-7bdc9d4dc8-dtkc2                                                  
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NGINX Ingress controller
  Release:       v1.1.1
  Build:         a17181e43ec85534a6fea968d95d019c5a4bc8cf
  Repository:    https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx
  nginx version: nginx/1.19.9

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

unknown flag: --size-buckets
Usage of :
unknown flag: --size-buckets
.....
.....
```

**What happened**:

I installed ingress-nginx using helm and tried to set the flag **size-buckets** as it looks that it exists https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/main/cmd/nginx/flags.go and according that feature described here https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/pull/7171.

The ingress-nginx deployment is successful but the pod is not starting and get the following message in pod logs "unknown flag: --size-buckets".

If try to use other flag, e.g. "enable-metrics" it works and accept the flag.

According the documentation at https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/main/docs/user-guide/cli-arguments.md, the flags time-buckets, length-buckets, size-buckets are not listed in list of arguments. 

So the question is, how can I set these flags?

So I have configured it to store the logs to a GCS bucket. Loki stores the data in the bucket as expected (I see a seed file, a 'fake' directory with many files whose names seem like UUIDs, and a directory index/index_loki_(number) with a file inside whose name starts with 'compactor'.

issue.body:
Hi,

issue.title: Not able to browse Documents folder in Mac
issue.body:
**Describe the bug**
Mac mojave and catalina has new file permission model to improve security (aka TCC). Applications now need to ask for permissions to access Documents/Downloads/Desktop folders.   I installed (and reinstalled multiple times) OWasp Zap in mac catalina 10.15.7. It starts up fine, however when trying to open a previously stored session (from another laptop) in my documents folder, I am not able to see any files/folder inside Documents folder. This is same for Desktop and downloads folder. (Presumably because of Mac's TCC permissions.). I tried resetting TCC for org.zaproxy.zap.ZAP and gave 'full disk' permissions to Zap. However even after that Zap is not able to see any files/folders in above folders.

**To Reproduce**
Steps to reproduce the behavior:
1. Open Zap
2. Click 'File' menu
3. Click 'Open Session'
4. Set file selector to 'All files.
5. Browse to Documents folder
6. Observe that no files/folders are visible.
7. If browseing to any other folder other than Documents/Downloads/Desktop folders, all files and folders are visible normally.

**Expected behavior**
Files/folder should be visible.

**Screenshots**
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3331518/107417382-6081f600-6aca-11eb-80f1-f3eb444ffe6f.png)

**Software versions**
 - ZAP: 2.10.0
 - Add-on: None
 - OS: MacOs Catalina 10.15.7 (19H2)
 - Java: Zap inbuilt jdk
 - Browser: Not applicable

**Errors from the zap.log file**
No errors in log file related to file dialog.

**Additional context**
Tried following things and none of them worked.
1) Tried reinstalling Zap multiple times. Zap never asked me for tcc permissions
2) Gave full disk permissions to Zap in Mac Privacy settings.
2) Reset tcc permissions using 'sudo tccutil reset All org.zaproxy.zap.ZAP'
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/3331518/107417736-be164280-6aca-11eb-92d5-d465f40209a6.png)


**Would you like to help fix this issue?**
Can provide any logs or debugging steps to reproduce the issue

Ideally, Zap could be made more compliant with Mac Tcc so it prompts for Tcc permission and shows up as available application to configure in Privacy settings for better management of TCC permissions.

comment.body:
> Same issues. "Full Access" didn't help.
> 
> Because I've given `Terminal.app` access, I'm able to access `~/Downloads` when I start it from the CLI as so:
> 
> ```
> $ /Applications/OWASP\ ZAP.app/Contents/Java/zap.sh
> ```

This is pretty annoying but at least it works, thanks.  I added an alias to my .zshrc

```bash
alias zap="/Applications/OWASP\ ZAP.app/Contents/Java/zap.sh 2>&1 > /dev/null  &"
```

So I just type `zap` in the terminal and am not bothered with the ouput.

issue.title: RPC memory usage - pods OOMkilled with 4GB allocated per pod
issue.body:
<!--
  First of all, thanks for your report/suggestion/whatever!

  This template is for bug reports. If you are reporting a bug, please continue on.
  If you are here for another reason, please, go to discussions: https://github.com/anycable/anycable/discussions

  Please, check the documentation website (https://docs.anycable.io/),
  especially, the "Troubleshooting" section (https://docs.anycable.io/troubleshooting)
  before submiting the issue.
-->

### Tell us about your environment

**Ruby version:**
3.1.2

**Rails version:**
7.0.4

**`anycable` gem version:**
1.2.3

**`anycable-rails` gem version:**
1.3.3

**`grpc` gem version:**
1.45.0

### What did you do?

I have been using AnyCable for a while already, but at the moment I am doing general load tests for our app with Locust.

### What did you expect to happen?

RPC process to function correctly with 4GB of RAM allocated per process/pod (Kubernetes).

### What actually happened?

The RPC processes get OOMKilled by Kubernetes very quickly and keep restarting, despite there isn't much activity really. 

Can you advise on how much memory each RPC process is supposed to use? I think that 4GB of RAM are already a lot considering that it's a single Rails process, and I have tried lowering the threads from 40 to 20, with no success. The RPC processes get OOMKilled in a very short time from restarting, so it doesn't happen after a while. Seems like a memory leak or something like that.

Thanks in advance for your help!

comment.body: Thanks @palkan , if it happens again I will try a different version of that gem.

issue.title: locust k8s operator
issue.body:
### Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.
Need for flexible, secure and easy to use distributed performance testing solution while enabling keeping in mind points like; cloud governance, k8s resource management, CI compatibility. 


### Describe the solution you'd like
A k8s operator

### Describe alternatives you've considered
HELM. However, this is not optimal as it requires a lot of manipulation and dealing with a lot of different k8s resource types not to mention lack of governance when deployed in an organisation. 

 
### Additional context
In my company, we were interested in cloud based distributed performance testing. We ended up choosing “locust” as a tool and I wrote a kubernetes operator for it. As far as I know and searched, this simply doesn’t exist for locust today.The operator have been running on AWS EKS for months now and it is very stable and performant.

The project was created to provide:
- A friendly user interface "A simple k8s custom resource based on a CRD"
- Ability to run a distributed performance testing
- Only ask for needed cluster permissions (security) 
- Exposing a Prometheus endpoint for test metrics
- Maintain cloud infrastructure governance i.e. when used in an organisation,  it is possible to maintain the governance over the allocated / created resources. 
- Cloud native by design 
- Enablement of performance testing in CI / CD pipelines

The project was inspired after doing an industry study / survey. 
The project was influenced in functionality by the k6 k8s operator.

As the code really doesn't include anything exclusive to the company, Open sourcing it is not a problem and it is something that I would happily do. 

What is the "catch"? 
The only "catch" is that the project is written in Java. That being said, from a user perspective, the interface purely through k8s and users are not exposed to any java code.  This is similar to how k8s and most operators are written in Go but non of k8s users need to know anything about Go. 

Looking forward to your feedback.

comment.body: Hi @AbdelrhmanHamouda ! This looks amazing! I checked the docs and would like to give it a try. How do I open the UI when a test is running?

issue.title: Document labels used by Okteto pods
issue.body:
**Is your feature request related to a problem? Please describe.**
Documentation request

**Describe the solution you'd like**
In my case, I use a wrapper around some K8s tools including Okteto to abstract some complexity, and am also using KEDA autoscaling to scale my app. When I start Okteto, the autoscaler interferes because it automatically starts its own non-Okteto pods, so traffic is then split between Okteto pods and the autoscaler pods, causing problems and confusion. For this reason, I changed my CLI so that before starting Okteto it patches the services so that they send traffic only to the Okteto pods, ignoring the autoscaled pods. So I can work with Okteto just fine. 

This wasn't documented, so I had to figure out that Okteto labels the pod for the main service with the label "interactive.dev.okteto.com" and the additional services (as specified in the manifest) with "detached.dev.okteto.com".

By patching my services to use these labels during an Okteto session, I no longer have problems due to the autoscaling.

**Describe alternatives you've considered**
I couldn't think of an alternative

comment.body: *_ssh_key_path settings require a relative path. The way you set them, the tool will look for the keys in the same directory where it is running. issue.title: post_create_commands and additional_packages
issue.body:
So, I have added to my config file code bellow. But I see also ability add some packages with `additional_packages`. How that works in different OS? and what about lifecycle? As I understand post_create_commands will be last one for running? If I want to update or add extra nodes will be additional_packages and post_create_commands run for active nodes? 

and how I can labeled nodes in setup way? Does it works https://github.com/vitobotta/hetzner-k3s/issues/98 ?

```
post_create_commands:
- apt update && apt upgrade -y
# Fix for K3s on Debian (Pods can't be scheduled)
- apt -y install apparmor apparmor-utils
#
- apt -y install mc htop vim wget git zsh podman iftop atop lsof fail2ban jq make
#
- apt -y install tmux tmuxinator
- git clone https://github.com/gpakosz/.tmux.git /root/.tmux ; ln -s -f /root/.tmux/.tmux.conf /root/ ; cp /root/.tmux/.tmux.conf.local /root/
#
- sh -c "$(wget https://raw.github.com/ohmyzsh/ohmyzsh/master/tools/install.sh -O -)" -y
- sed -i 's/\/bin\/bash/\/usr\/bin\/zsh/g' /etc/passwd
- /usr/bin/git clone https://github.com/zsh-users/zsh-autosuggestions /root/.oh-my-zsh/custom/plugins/zsh-autosuggestions
- sed -i 's/plugins=(git)/plugins=(zsh-autosuggestions git docker docker-compose poetry kubectl)/g' /root/.zshrc
#
- apt autoremove -y
- shutdown -r now
```

comment.body: @maxclax Nice to hear that you haven't had any problems with the binaries, other people have. Ruby isn't really great for this since it's not compiled, that's why I am rewriting it in Crystal.

comment.body:
Hi, 

- installing packages you specify happens only once the nodes are first created. If you want to upgrade them or install something else after the fact, you need to SSH into the nodes and do it manually.
- The machines are provided by default with Ubuntu unless you specify another image, so the packages and the commands you specify should match that
- If you add new nodes to an existing cluster, it will run the post commands and install the additional packages on them as expected
- the node labelling was introduced in v0.6.2 IIRC but I recommend you use the gem because there are some issues with the binaries. I am currently rewriting the tool in Crystal to be able to offer proper binaries and solve some other issues I have with the Ruby version. If you have problems with 0.6.2 I recommend you stick to a release from before I introduced this changes, 0.5.9 and label the nodes manually for now.

issue.body: I have some clusters/context in my config file ~/.kube/config. But after create new cluster by hetzner-k3s all my config changed only with new data of new cluster. How can I create new cluster with add new data like new context, not cleaning previous data of clusters.

comment.body: Hi, that should not happen. The tool writes the kubeconfig to the file you specify in the config file. Did you set it to ~/.kube/config? I recommend to specify another file, maybe in the same locations as the config file, and then manually copy it to whereever you want.

issue.title: Use of cache doesn't seem to speed up much
issue.body:
## Expected Behavior

Using cache should improve performance significantly.

## Actual Behavior

For example I have an endpoint that serializes 7700 records that also include associations. The queries are fast, but generating the serialized response takes 5 seconds at least (I'm already using the oj gem).

I have enabled caching and I can see it creates one individual Redis key for each record and for its associated records too.
But the serialization takes more or less the same time basically.

## Steps to Reproduce the Problem

  1. Add caching configuration to the relevant models (main model as well as the associated models)
  2. Run the serializer the first time, it creates the keys in Redis
  3. Run the serializer the second time with the same data, this is not faster than without caching

## Specifications

  - Version: 2.2.0
  - Ruby version: 3.1.2


Thanks in advance.

issue.body:
NGINX Ingress controller
Release: v1.1.1
nginx version: nginx/1.19.9

**Kubernetes version (use kubectl version):**

Server Version: version.Info{Major:"1", Minor:"20+", GitVersion:"v1.20.12-gke.1500", GitCommit:"d32c0db9a3ccd0ac73b0b3abd0532505217b376e", GitTreeState:"clean", BuildDate:"2021-11-17T09:30:02Z", GoVersion:"go1.15.15b5", Compiler:"gc", Platform:"linux/amd64"}

**Helm version:**
version.BuildInfo{Version:"v3.7.0", GitCommit:"eeac83883cb4014fe60267ec6373570374ce770b", GitTreeState:"clean", GoVersion:"go1.16.8"}

**Environment:**
- Cloud provider or hardware configuration: GCP GKE
- OS (e.g. from /etc/os-release): Container-Optimized OS from Google 
- Kernel version: 5.4.144+

How was the ingress-nginx-controller installed:
Using helm template , using the command: 

`helm install ingress-nginx ingress-nginx/ingress-nginx --set controller.extraArgs.size-buckets="{0.05,0.1,0.3,0.5,1.0,5,10}"`

Output of 'helm ls -A | grep -i ingress'
ingress-nginx	default  	1       	2022-02-10 12:35:46.167462946 +0200 EET	deployed	ingress-nginx-4.0.17	1.1.1 

**Current State of the controller**:

➜  kubectl get pod
NAME                                        READY   STATUS             RESTARTS   AGE
ingress-nginx-controller-7bdc9d4dc8-dtkc2   0/1     CrashLoopBackOff   10         27m
```

```
➜  kubectl describe ingressclasses
Name:         nginx
Labels:       app.kubernetes.io/component=controller
              app.kubernetes.io/instance=ingress-nginx
              app.kubernetes.io/managed-by=Helm
              app.kubernetes.io/name=ingress-nginx

              app.kubernetes.io/version=1.1.1

              meta.helm.sh/release-namespace: default
Controller:   k8s.io/ingress-nginx
Events:       <none>
```


```
➜  ~ kubectl logs -f ingress-nginx-controller-7bdc9d4dc8-dtkc2                                                  
-------------------------------------------------------------------------------
NGINX Ingress controller
  Release:       v1.1.1

  Repository:    https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx

-------------------------------------------------------------------------------

unknown flag: --size-buckets
Usage of :
unknown flag: --size-buckets
.....
.....
```

**What happened**:

I installed ingress-nginx using helm and tried to set the flag **size-buckets** as it looks that it exists https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/main/cmd/nginx/flags.go and according that feature described here https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/pull/7171.

The ingress-nginx deployment is successful but the pod is not starting and get the following message in pod logs "unknown flag: --size-buckets".

If try to use other flag, e.g. "enable-metrics" it works and accept the flag.

According the documentation at https://github.com/kubernetes/ingress-nginx/blob/main/docs/user-guide/cli-arguments.md, the flags time-buckets, length-buckets, size-buckets are not listed in list of arguments. 

So the question is, how can I set these flags?

I have configured the Puma instrumentation as per the README but I only see the worker related metrics. I would need to see puma_request_backlog for example but it doesn't show up in Prometheus. What am I missing? Thanks!

ps. This is in my puma.rb

```ruby
on_worker_boot do
  if Rails.env.production?
    require 'prometheus_exporter/instrumentation'

    PrometheusExporter::Instrumentation::ActiveRecord.start(
      custom_labels: { type: "puma_worker" }, #optional params
      config_labels: [:database, :host] #optional params
    )

    PrometheusExporter::Instrumentation::Process.start(type: "web")
    PrometheusExporter::Instrumentation::Puma.start
  end
end
```
